title-group.article-title: Further Concerns Regarding Opioids after Tonsillectomy in Children

body.p: Drs Cheng and Sobol’s recently published survey1 of graduating otolaryngology residents highlights the incomplete dispersion of knowledge regarding posttonsillectomy pain management. The authors expressed concern that 8% of respondents selected acetaminophen with codeine as their first choice for pain control in this setting despite the recent Food and Drug Administration (FDA) warning against its routine use, especially in children with upper airway obstruction.2 Published reports of death after administration of appropriate doses of codeine preparations in children with ultra-rapid metabolizing variants of cytochrome P4502D6 (CYP2D6) document toxic serum levels of morphine, the active metabolite of codeine. There are more than 80 known allelic variants of the CYP2D6 gene. According to the FDA warning, between 1% and 29% of all children may be ultra-rapid metabolizers, depending on ethnicity.

Cheng and Sobol1 do not comment on the prudence of prescribing the other common opioids (oxycodone and hydrocodone) in their study. Together these agents were preferred by 53% of senior residents. Both of these opioids are metabolized by P4502D6 (CYP2D6) (oxycodone to oxymorphone and noroxymorphone3–hydrocodone to hydromorphone4) and thus share the risks of variable metabolism. Sadhasivam and Myer5 queried the LexisNexis database between 1984 and 2010 for death and injury claims following tonsillectomy. They found that 18% of death claims and 5% of hypoxic brain injuries were related to opioids. They advocate for the routine use of acetaminophen in combination with ibuprofen for management of posttonsillectomy pain. Our group began using a combination of around-the-clock ibuprofen (7 mg/kg/dose every 4 hours) supplemented with acetaminophen for all pediatric tonsillectomy patients 2 years ago. Like the Cincinnati Children’s team, we have found the combination highly effective—nearly eliminating the use of opioids.

Although preoperative testing for P4502D6 (CYP2D6) genotypes is available, such testing has not become common practice. Consideration should be given to replacing the unreliable opioid pain relievers with well-tolerated nonnarcotic analgesics for the majority of children after tonsillectomy.
